abstract: Mukesh Ambani’s Reliance Industries was ordered to sell natural gas to a company owned by his younger brother, Anil, for 44 percent less than the government-set price, lawyers said.
snippet: Mukesh Ambani’s Reliance Industries was ordered to sell natural gas to a company owned by his younger brother, Anil, for 44 percent less than the government-set price, lawyers said.
lead_paragraph: Mukesh Ambani’s Reliance Industries, India’s most valuable company, was ordered to sell natural gas to a company owned by his younger brother, Anil, for 44 percent less than the government-set price, lawyers said. The high court in Mumbai, formerly Bombay, ruled the company had to honor a 2005 agreement to supply 28 million cubic meters of gas a day at $2.34 for each million British thermal units for 17 years, said Mukul Rohatgi, counsel for Anil Ambani’s Reliance Natural Resources. Reliance Industries will decide on its “future course of action based on legal advice,” it said in an e-mailed message.

headline.main: India: Verdict Favors Anil Ambani Over Brother
headline.print_headline: India: Verdict Favors Anil Ambani Over Brother

abstract: A PBS documentary works hard to portray Kenneth D. Lewis, BofA’s chief, as the victim of a bullying government and an entitled Wall Street bonus culture, The New York Times’s Gina Bellafante writes.
snippet: A PBS documentary works hard to portray Kenneth D. Lewis, BofA’s chief, as the victim of a bullying government and an entitled Wall Street bonus culture, The New York Times’s Gina Bellafante writes.
lead_paragraph: Central to the “Frontline” franchise is the notion that the little guy is always right and deserving of our sympathies, apparently even if his personal fortune might exceed many city council budgets by a factor of 100, The New York Times’s Gina Bellafante writes.

headline.main: Looking for the Little Guy Among Wall Street Giants
